FYI, a few more reactions and articles on the same topic.  It looks like
mo=
st of the Java and Ruby communities (last link) are typically using a
small=
 portion of TDD and a majority of regular testing, which matches my
experie=
nce.

The good news is that they're all testing.

On 8/3/06, C=C3=A9dric Beust =E2=99=94 <cbeust@...> wrote=
:
>
>
>
> On 8/3/06, Robert Martin < UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
> =
> > Hehe... If I'm a heretic because I recommend using your common sense
> =
> > instead of one-liners such as "always test first", then yes, guilty as
=
> > > charged :-)
> >
> > I have grown intolerant of the attitude that test=
ing is optional.
>
>
> I never said testing was optional.
>
> I don't know =
about you, but what makes my job fascinating is that it's a
> constant mix =
of tasks with sometimes conflicting objectives:
>
>    - Designing
>    - W=
orking with product managers
>    - Coding
>    - Debugging
>    - Testing
=
>    - Working with tech writers
>    - Shipping
>    - Supporting
>
> I am=
 paid to make decisions in all these areas and prioritize them, and in
> or=
der to ship good software, you need to score very well on all of these
> co=
unts.
>
> The respective priorities of these tasks change depending on whic=
h cycle
> in your software development you are, and while testing is a high=
 priority
> task in my mind at all times, it's obvious that at some point, =
it needs to
> be preempted by more urgent tasks.
>
> What makes someone a g=
ood professional is knowing when such a situation
> arises.
>
> What makes =
someone a bad professional is when they put a task at the top
> of their pr=
iority regardless of the context.
>
>  --
> C=C3=A9dric

<http://www.google.com/url?sa=3DD&q=3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ftestng.org>
